BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the often large wind slabs can be released easily or naturally.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls avalanche prone wind slabs formed. Many large natural avalanches are possible. The new snow and wind slabs of the last two days can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, in all aspects and generally at intermediate and high altitudes.

The current avalanche situation calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 40 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1600 m. As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, large wind slabs formed in the last two days in particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as at intermediate and high altitudes.
The new snow is lying on a crust on sunny slopes. This snow is lying on soft layers on shady slopes and at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. In its middle, the snowpack is largely stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls avalanche prone wind slabs formed. Some large natural avalanches are possible. The new snow and wind slabs of the last two days can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects and generally above the tree line. As a consequence of the strong westerly wind the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent as the day progresses.

The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 20 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, large wind slabs formed in the last two days in particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as at intermediate and high altitudes. In addition further wind slabs will form as the day progresses.
The new snow is lying on a crust on sunny slopes. This snow is lying on soft layers on shady slopes and at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
The old snowpack is largely stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the wind slabs can be released easily or naturally.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a strong westerly wind, avalanche prone wind slabs formed in particular at high altitude. Wind slabs can in many places be released, even by a single winter sport participant and reach large size.
The new snow of the last three days is bonding only slowly with the old snowpack. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible over a wide area.
Increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches until the temperature drops.

The current avalanche situation calls for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 60 to 80 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1800 m. As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, large wind slabs formed in the last two days in particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as at intermediate and high altitudes.
The new snow is lying on a crust on sunny slopes. This snow is lying on soft layers on shady slopes and at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. The old snowpack is largely stable.

The snowpack will become moist at low and intermediate altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger. Backcountry touring calls for experience and a certain restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from southerly directions, further wind slabs will form in the course of the day adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as above the tree line. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above the tree line. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. Some natural avalanches are possible. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines, as well as at the base of rock walls. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized. On steep grassy slopes more medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible. As a consequence of warming during the day more frequent moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected. This applies in particular on very steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 10 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Wednesday above approximately 1500 m. The wind was strong to storm force at times. In places that are protected from the wind wind slabs formed. These are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in all aspects above the tree line. The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In the afternoon as a consequence of new snow and strong wind there will be only a slight increase in the avalanche danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow and in particular the wind slabs formed during the snowfall can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above the tree line. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible, in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
In all aspects more frequent small and medium-sized loose snow avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of warming during the day, in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2200 m, as well as at the base of rock walls.
Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last few days above approximately 1500 m. The wind was strong to storm force at times. In places that are protected from the wind sometimes large wind slabs formed. These are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in all aspects above the tree line.
5 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Friday above approximately 1800 m.
The wind slabs will be covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some regions 20 to 30 cm of snow will fall on Saturday above approximately 2000 m. New snow and wind slabs require caution. The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of warming during the day the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses. The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence at intermediate and high altitudes. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation. In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible as a consequence of new snow and wind.
Gradual increase in danger of moist avalanches as a consequence of warming. The rain will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. Individual gliding avalanches can also occur. Avalanches can be released, even by a single winter sport participant. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in all aspects. The weather report and anticipated change in the avalanche danger are uncertain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind will be strong over a wide area. The new snow and wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack in many places. The weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack over a wide area. Individual weak layers exist in the old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
The weather will be cloudy over a wide area. The wind will be strong.
Over a wide area the wind slabs will increase in size additionally.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated critically.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a strong to storm force wind, further wind slabs will form. These can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on very steep northwest, north and east facing slopes. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2200 m. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude.

On steep grassy slopes more medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2200 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of warming during the day more frequent moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected. This applies on extremely steep slopes in all aspects, in the event of prolonged bright spells especially.

Backcountry touring calls for experience and a certain restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Wednesday. Some snow will fall on Friday in some localities.
The wind will be strong to storm force. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on northwest to north to east facing aspects at elevated altitudes. The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: From midday as a consequence of new snow and strong wind there will be only a slight increase in the avalanche danger. Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh wind slabs can be released easily.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a strong westerly wind, avalanche prone wind slabs formed in particular at high altitude. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. As a consequence of the wind the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent as the day progresses. Wind slabs can in many places be released, even by a single winter sport participant and reach large size in isolated cases.
Small and medium-sized natural avalanches are further possible.

The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last two days in particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as at intermediate and high altitudes. In addition further wind slabs will form as the day progresses. The new snow is lying on a crust in particular on east to south to west facing aspects. In its middle, the snowpack is largely stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A precarious avalanche situation will persist in some cases. Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated critically.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a strong to storm force wind, further wind slabs will form. These can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on very steep west, north and southeast facing slopes. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2200 m. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude.
Isolated natural avalanches are possible. This applies in particular on very steep shady slopes adjacent to ridgelines especially in high Alpine regions. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized.

On steep grassy slopes more medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2200 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of warming during the day more frequent moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected. This applies on extremely steep slopes in all aspects, in the event of prolonged bright spells especially.

Backcountry touring calls for extensive experience and a certain restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
25 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Wednesday. Some snow will fall on Friday in some localities.
The wind will be strong to storm force. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on west to north to southeast facing aspects at elevated altitudes. The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: From midday as a consequence of new snow and strong wind there will be an increase in the avalanche danger within the current danger level. 15 to 30 cm of snow will fall. Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and very particularly the wind slabs represent the main danger. These are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The strong wind will transport the new snow significantly. The wind slabs will be deposited on soft layers at intermediate and high altitudes.
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong wind from southerly directions, further wind slabs will form in the course of the day adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above the tree line. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, in all aspects. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more widespread and the danger is slightly greater.

During the day: More dry and moist avalanches are possible, even medium-sized ones, in particular on very steep sunny slopes, and on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 40 cm of snow, and up to 60 cm in some localities, has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 2000 m, in particular along the border with Switzerland.
On Thursday the wind was moderate to strong.
Friday: Little snow will fall until the evening.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
The old snowpack is favourably layered.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will increase during the day. Dry and moist avalanches are to be expected as the precipitation becomes more intense.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the large wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain easily released wind slabs will form. Skiers can release avalanches very easily, including large ones. Remotely triggered and natural avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowfall will give rise as the day progresses to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area in particular on steep slopes. The fresh wind slabs are difficult even for the trained eye to recognise and to be assessed with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. The wind slabs are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The strong wind will transport the new snow significantly. The wind slabs will be deposited on soft layers at intermediate and high altitudes.
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong wind from southerly directions, further wind slabs will form in the course of the day adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above the tree line. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, in all aspects. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more widespread and the danger is slightly greater.

During the day: More dry and moist avalanches are possible, even medium-sized ones, in particular on very steep sunny slopes, and on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
25 to 40 cm of snow, and up to 60 cm in some localities, has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 2000 m. This applies in particular along the border with Switzerland.
On Thursday the wind was moderate to strong.
Friday: Little snow will fall until the evening.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes, in particular along the border with Switzerland.
The old snowpack is favourably layered.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will increase during the day. Dry and moist avalanches are to be expected as the precipitation becomes more intense.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The danger of moist and wet avalanches will increase during the day. In addition the wind slabs should be taken into account.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases above approximately 2000 m. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Some natural avalanches are possible. On very steep grassy slopes more gliding avalanches are possible. As a consequence of warming during the day more frequent moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected. This applies in particular on very steep slopes in particular below approximately 2000 m, as well as at the base of rock walls. Sometimes avalanches are medium-sized.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 5 to 20 cm of snow has fallen since Wednesday above approximately 1700 m. The wind was strong to storm force at times. In places that are protected from the wind wind slabs formed. These are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in all aspects above the tree line. The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In the afternoon as a consequence of new snow and strong wind there will be only a slight increase in the avalanche danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the sometimes deep wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above approximately 2500 m. As a consequence of the precipitation medium-sized wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The sleet will give rise as the day progresses to rapid and thorough wetting of the old snowpack below approximately 2500 m. The fresh wind slabs are difficult even for the trained eye to recognise and to be assessed with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated critically.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a strong to storm force wind, further wind slabs will form. These can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on very steep northwest, north and east facing slopes. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2200 m. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude.

On steep grassy slopes gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes at elevated altitudes, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2200 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of warming during the day more frequent moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected. This applies on extremely steep slopes in all aspects, in the event of prolonged bright spells especially.

Backcountry touring calls for experience and a certain restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Wednesday. Some snow will fall on Friday in some localities.
The wind will be strong to storm force. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on northwest to north to east facing aspects at elevated altitudes. The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: From midday as a consequence of new snow and strong wind there will be only a slight increase in the avalanche danger. Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow slides and avalanches are possible in isolated cases. Mostly these are small.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual mostly small wet snow slides and avalanches are possible above approximately 1900 m. In gullies and bowls a sometimes precarious avalanche situation will be encountered in some localities.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 1900 m hardly any snow is lying. The older wind slabs are to be found especially in gullies and bowls and at high altitudes. As a consequence of the precipitation, the likelihood of wet snow slides and avalanches being released will increase.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The sleet will give rise as the day progresses to rapid and thorough wetting of the old snowpack below approximately 1700 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche prone locations are very rare and are easy to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally wet all the way through.
